awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Undergraduate Research in Mathematics, Applied Mathematics, and Statistics at Lafayette College
awd_abstract_narration:
The Lafayette College REU Site will run for eight weeks in the summer and one week in the academic year for three years.  Each summer, three faculty mentors, including one mentor a year from outside Lafayette, will work daily with ten students from across the US on groundbreaking research projects in mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics.  Students will develop strong research skills as well as become effective communicators, both orally and in writing.  Summer activities will include renowned guest speakers and other programming on a wide variety of topics to enhance students' professional development and curiosity.  The guidance provided by the faculty mentors will continue throughout the following academic year, culminating in presentations at the Joint Mathematics Meetings and the preparation of articles to submit to high-quality journals. This program will put students in very strong positions to be successful in the mathematical sciences after graduation.  Further, the faculty themselves will be mentored by previous REU advisors, with a particular focus on the faculty who have limited experience in leading undergraduate research; this mentoring will run year-round. Thus, both students and faculty will grow through the REU, and they will return to their home institutions energized by the experience and ready to continue conducting research.  

A diverse selection of research projects will be offered, appropriate for a combination of rising sophomores, juniors, and seniors each year and targeting a wide range of prior mathematical and statistical training. Students early in their mathematical education can engage in research on roughly half of the projects, including those focusing on permutation patterns and statistics, geometric network optimization, and block coloring problems. Other projects include research on symmetries in affine geometry, infinite groups and cube complexes, and the Kelly Criterion for investments. With close mentoring, the advisors will lead their students to greater independence and a strong sense of collegiality; this will provide an excellent foundation in the research process. The students will actively contribute to new knowledge in mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation funded REU Site: Undergraduate Research in Mathematics, Applied Mathematics, and Statistics at Lafayette College ran for three summers, 2017-2019, and the work continued for more than six months after the conclusion of the summer portion of the program. Each summer, three faculty mentors, including at least one mentor a year from a college other than Lafayette, worked daily with ten students from across the US on a diverse selection of research projects in mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics. After the summer, students and faculty continued work on finishing and writing up their results.  So far, two papers have been published in respected journals, and two more papers are under review.  The remaining groups are still working on their results, so we expect additional papers to be published.  In addition, the students collectively gave 30 scientific presentations about their work, both at national and regional math conferences and in their own institutions, and many of these students actively encouraged other students to apply to REUs. They also presented 19 posters at various conferences, 5 of which earned Outstanding Poster awards! 

The thirty students who participated included 19 women and 11 men, including a Hispanic student, and most of the students came from schools without masters or PhD programs, where there are fewer opportunities to participate in hands-on, active research. These students can help to change the face of mathematics, increasing the representation of traditionally under-represented groups in mathematics.

The REU mentors who were drawn from colleges outside of Lafayette had the opportunity to experience a vibrant research community during the summer months.  Due to the nature of their colleges, many of them did not have the opportunity to conduct high-level research with undergraduates. These mentors returned to their home institutions eager to continue working with undergraduates on mathematics research and endeavored to find opportunities at their institutions to continue the work they had done during the REU. Further, some of these mentors have explored new projects they became interested in.  The REU directors held regular ?mentoring the mentors? meetings, and even the experienced mentors found the discussions helpful and engaging.  The final effect is increased engagement in research with undergraduates.

As a regular part of the REU program, the students attended talks and a conference, and there were regular discussions about a variety of topics, showing them the breadth and depth of mathematics. There were also social events to encourage students to see that mathematics can be fun as well as interesting and hard. The students were energized by the experience.  Several of the groups continue to meet, including one that still meets every Saturday night, more than two years after the end of the REU.  As one student said, ?[Y]our socialization goals for the REU were wildly successful.?  Most of the 30 participants have received their undergraduate degrees, and all of them are in graduate school in mathematics or related fields, are planning on going to graduate school, or are working in a mathematics-related area.
